awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Proof -Of-Concept for Large-Scale and Low-Cost Biomass Production Using an Innovative Open Aquatic Algae Cultivation System (OAACS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to establish the proof-of-concept of using an innovative open aquatic algae cultivation system (OAACS) to overcome scale and cost constraints of current large-scale algal biomass production systems like raceway ponds. Drop-in biofuels derived from OAACS’ biomass have a projected minimum fuel selling price of $2.53/gasoline gallon equivalent, which is competitive with fossil fuels, and have potential production scales that exceed current global fossil fuel usage. Successful commercialization of OAACS can lead to new sustainable energy sources, significant displacement of fossil fuel use, and concomitant reductions in the future environmental and societal impacts of global climate change. If successful, OAACS can also pave the way for sustainable, competitive, and meaningfully large-scale production of other bioproducts like fertilizers and high protein feeds.

The proposed project aims to fabricate robust liners for OAACS using an innovative forced assembly co-extrusion and two-dimensional multiplication technique and then demonstrate their performance in OAACS scale-down laboratory photobioreactors. The minimum success criterion is production of liners that support sustained algal aerial yields >15 g ash free dry weight/m2/day for weeks or months without the need for liner cleaning or CO2 supplementation. This will establish feasibility that OAACS can meet production scale- and cost-targets. Tasks include: 1. Fabrication and physical characterization of base case liners using previously demonstrated techniques and then extending results to liners with pore size gradients and surface modified nanofibers; 2. Demonstrating high dissolved inorganic carbon transfer rates through the liners; and 3. Demonstrating robust performance of the liners during continuous culturing in laboratory photobioreactors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The broader outcome of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is significant advancement towards establishing the proof-of-concept of using an innovative open aquatic algae cultivation system (OAACS) to overcome scale and cost constraints of current large-scale algal biomass production systems like raceway ponds.

The project fabricated liners for OAACS using an innovative forced assembly co-extrusion and two-dimensional multiplication technique and expanded its work to include liners fabricated using other methods. The liners were tested for their ability to retain microalgae and their mass transfer properties were characterized. Important structure/function relationships were established and a clear liner synthesis strategy was developed that evolves over time. Future work will initially rely on manufacturing technologies that are already commercially enabled, while continued development of new technologies will enable manufacture of liners with enhanced properties for future deployment. Laboratory procedures necessary for establishing proof-of-concept were tested and problems with some materials were clearly identified and plans were formulated to overcome them. The project's results indicate that future work should quickly lead to production of liners that support sustained algal aerial yields >15 g ash free dry weight/m2/day without the need for carbon dioxide supplementation along with establishment of proof-of-concept for OAACS use at large scales. If continuation of the project is successful and results in affordable large scale microalgal biomass generation and its conversion into bioproducts like feeds, food, fuels, and fertilizers, then major impacts such as improvements to employment, the environment, and standards of living should take place.


Last Modified: 09/16/2024
Modified by: Stuart Bussell
